newsitem.title: JAPAN: Japan steel mills bank on houses as markets shrink.
newsitem.headline: Japan steel mills bank on houses as markets shrink.

text.p: Faced with waning demand from their mainstay customers in the car and electronics industries, Japanese steel mills are banking on the booming housing market.

Steelmakers such as Nippon Steel Corp, Kawasaki Steel Corp and Sumitomo Metal Industries Ltd are promoting steel-framed housing in a country with a traditional and enduring attachment to wooden homes.

The steelmakers are looking to carve out a lucrative new market for their steel products as many of their traditional customers in Japan's manufacturing industry have shifted their production -- and steel orders -- overseas.

Kawasaki Steel built an experimental steel-framed house in Japan last autumn. In cooperation with locally based contractors, the company plans to start construction of at least six steel-framed houses in the current business year, company officials said.
Nippon Steel and NKK Corp, Japan's two largest steelmakers, said they had also started building several steel-framed houses this year.
In Japan, which has sweltering summers and is prone to earthquakes, houses have traditionally been made of wood.

"We were faced with the question of how to make up for the fall in domestic demand as our big customers moved their production overseas," said Tomohiko Kimura, a general manager at the flat rolled products division at Sumitomo Metal Industries. "One of the answers was steel-framed houses."

Steel-framed houses use formed galvanised steel sheet. Coated with zinc to prevent rusting, it has been used mainly for automobile bodies and home appliances such as refrigerators and washing machines.

But domestic demand for steel products has been declining steadily since the early 1990s in light of the so-called "hollowing out" of the economy, caused by major manufacturers shifting production overseas to cut costs.

Demand for galvanised steel sheet in Japan was more than 10 million tonnes in 1991, but had dropped to 8.4 million tonnes in 1995. Galvanised steel sheet is also a very lucrative product for steelmakers. The sheet is currently marketed at around 100,000 yen ($900) per tonne, compared with 45,000 yen ($405) for H-shaped steel bars.
The Kozai Club, a steel industry organisation, is backing the steelmakers' efforts and aims to obtain government approval for this type of steel-framed housing as early as next April.

It said it plans to make the steel frame system available to all home builders throughout Japan in the hope of popularising steel-framed houses. It also plans to set up an organisation for training builders and accrediting contractors.
A Kozai Club official said that if 200,000 steel-framed houses were constructed annually this could create demand for one million tonnes of galvanised steel sheet.
A house with floor space of about 150 square metres would use five tonnes of the steel sheet.

The housing market has been booming in Japan due to rock-bottom interest rates. In 1995, there were 1.47 million housing starts in Japan and economists predict that the figure is likely to reach 1.5 million this year.

"In order for steel-framed houses to attract future home owners, the new housing system must prove that it is as comfortable as wood-structured houses to live in and that it has cost advantages," said Haruo Masuda, a general manager in Kawasaki Steel's construction materials department.
Kimura said Sumitomo Metal Industries would be able to supply steel frames at a price 20 to 30 percent lower than that of wooden frames.

Michikatsu Hirano, a professor of architecture at the Science University of Tokyo, said that, at least in theory, steel-framed houses could offer the same structural durability and other qualities as conventional houses. ($1=111 yen)
